commentBody: Delightful, thank you!
This puzzle I like!!
I have enjoyed Victor Barocas puzzles over the years. I liked this one too, but I thought it was too easy for a Wednesday. YMMV.
Fun, that was!
Did this puz, I done.

Successful operation. Well, operations. The hike and the streak. Surprisingly we had a cell signal at the top of the mountain. Perhaps even more surprisingly, it was strong enough to load the crossword but not strong enough to load the comments. So you get yesterday's comment now.

I keep a bottle of BELVEDEREVODKA in my freezer for one purpose. To celebrate Iga Swiatek titles. It stays in the freezer up until she's a game away from winning a title.

A puzzle right up my alley this was.  Tons of musical clues, most of them intersecting with Star Wars, I watched a SIXERS game this evening, and I‚Äôve used an ATRA razor for decades.  I did have to use some crosses to figure out how to morph I Can See For Miles into FORMILESICANSEE (perhaps I should have checked the revealer), but I got it quickly enough and the puzzle was a snap after that.  Lots of fun with this I had.

I loved the Yoda theme.  I knew three of the four songs immediately but had trouble fitting the crossing clues, then that was a great lightbulb moment.

Most of the puzzle was on the easier side for a Wednesday puzzle, but the middle was really tough for me.  Just crossing DVORAK and SIBERIA with PRELL and OBIE.  Three things I've never heard of and a fourth that depends on geography trivia.

Same with crossing of RIAL with ALTA, that ended up being a 'Guess every letter' square for me.

Solve this puzzle, I did.

Trying to fit other song titles to the Yoda-speak theme should be a lot of fun. I'll leave it to y'all. 
Last puzzle for a couple weeks for me, I'll be on the road.

My initials thoughts are very positive.  I caught onto the trick with the titles before I knew the hilarious reason why we were doing it.

Just a pleasure to solve.

A thousand thanks, Mr. Barocas.  It was a hoot and a half.

"To baldly go where no man has gone before."

First I had Iran / Inuit, and while I quickly corrected the error, I also paused to reflect on what it would be like if there were a people called Take This Job and Shove It. Like on a census, if asked to describe your ethnicity, you'd fill in Take This Job and Shove It. Or you just got hired for your dream job, and the new boss asks about your background and your family. "My people come from Yugoslavia and Macedonia," she said, "how about yours?" 

"Take This Job and Shove It," you reply proudly. "I'm one quarter Take This Job and Shove it" and the rest Siberian. Omsk to be exact." 

Then I plowed ahead and completed the thing, amused by the puzzle more than I amused myself. Or, as Eddie-Yoda would say, "This puzzle I done did."
My mother used Prell. I can smell it in my mind!  Remember the old commercials where the lady put a pearl in the bottle & you watched it go down ‚Ä¶ very slowly?  What a trip down memory lane!

So I hate to be less than exuberant about a puzzle with a YODA theme, that references Kirk and Picard (loved that clue), and highlights OSU that just whipped Michigan (go Buckeyes), as I sit in sunny Sarasota FLA about an eighth of a mile from the Tamiami Trail, my return to Ohio after Thanksgiving weekend delayed by the snow. But alas I did find it a bit ho-hum otherwise. Yeah I got a fleeting smile from the theme entries but not sure why finding random song titles that you can YODA-ize has much to do with anything and the fill and clues seemed pretty bland and straightforward. Still, it was a cute idea and I‚Äôll take it for what it was.
It appears that the overall grade given to this Wednesday puzzle by you folks was: LUKE-warm.

I‚Äôm not very good with songs and artists unless it‚Äôs Billy Joel. So I was working my way around the grid trying to get easy downs to help when I got THESHERIFF. My brain immediately went to She shot the Sheriff and figured out the theme. That helped tremendously. Loved Star Trek/ Star Wars clues. Idea clued the same way within 4 days is odd.
ASL=Yoda speak

I wanted to take a moment to recognize the passing of one of the great wordsmiths of this or any generation, Tom Stoppard. I found a quote of his that I believe everyone on this forum can finally agree on and appreciate:

‚ÄúWords... They're innocent, neutral, precise, standing for this, describing that, meaning the other, so if you look after them you can build bridges across incomprehension and chaos. But when they get their corners knocked off, they're no good any more... I don't think writers are sacred, but words are. They deserve respect. If you get the right ones in the right order, you can nudge the world a little or make a poem which children will speak for you when you're dead.‚Äù

and two more of my favorites:

‚ÄúLife is a gamble, at terrible odds. If it were a bet you wouldn‚Äôt take it.‚Äù

‚ÄúEternity is a terrible thought. I mean, where‚Äôs it going to end?‚Äù

I‚Äôm just scratching the surface, I‚Äôll let you discover more yourself if you haven‚Äôt already. Farewell, Sir Stoppard, thank you for sharing your wit, wisdom and humor with us. You will be missed.

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot! It definitely made me smile. Or, you could say:

Made of this, sweet dreams are

Dvorak's Slavonic Dances were originally written for piano four-hands, and later orchestrated by the composer. Here's a YouTube video of two distinguished pianists (Yuja Wang and Andras Schiff) performing two of the dances: - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0ukuHdWGOI It's a study in contrasts, in more ways than one.

Cute theme, middle was a dense trivia slog.

Who song could have used better hinting IMO.
Omg howling ü§£üòùüòúü§™
THE SHERIFF IS HOT!

My husband and I learned some time back that what we‚Äôd previously described as ‚ÄúYoda-speak‚Äù was formally ‚Äúanastrophe‚Äù ‚Äî the ‚Äúinversion of the usual syntactical order of words for rhetorical effect.‚Äù

I love music and know three of the four songs quite well, so I enjoyed this even if it was a little on the easy side. My only real slowdown was at 57A, where I originally tried to make wrEsTs work. 

Thanks for the fun, Mr. Barocas!

This puzzle on this day satisfied my particular wishes for challenge and ease, misdirects and redos, quick fill and guesses, solvable spans, and TILs.

A delight! 

My favorite entry was LODE for ‚ÄúA miner celebration?‚Äù ‚õèÔ∏è

always a pleasure (not that it happens to me a lot) to fill three of the four thematic grid spanners de novo after one falls into place with crosses.  didnt even need the yoda.
for me, thats the platonic form of a theme.
a whoopie wednesday grid.
Fun this puzzle was
Shouldn't it be: "for miles see I can"? And "a  girl kissed I" and so on?

You‚Äôre either balding or bald  and amongst us there are some balder than the others. But we aren‚Äôt BALDER than the ones with hair. 

We reserve those distinctions for ourselves üòÄ
also, with the laziest of jedi mind tricks and a tipsy crowd, yoda would be a master karaoke practitioner.
So much potential, but feels like the author / editor just put in 50% effort then get lazy and fill the rest in with obscure trivia and poor cluing and call it a day, again.

A fun theme that was, like it I did üòÉ. (I bet all comments begin like that today, but there really is no other way with a theme like this)

The fill was a bit hard for me in places but I dealt with it in the end without Google's help. I was unfamiliar with The Who title, which was my biggest problem today.

I didn't understand PEDS when it emerged from crosses but it was covered by the column.
As a massive star wars fan I'm bummed this puzzle wasn't a more satisfying fill, Egyptian sun god and PRELL probably being my two least favorite. Undercooked, this puzzle was, hmmmm?
Delightful puzzle  I feel I'm over the rainbow somewhere.

No YodaSpeak here, just hats off to one of the most fun, yet edifying puzzles of the year. Of course I knew the names of each song and punched them into all the spaces without any knowledge of the theme. And then found myself totally baffled when the puzzle fell apart. Nothing was making sense. So I concentrated and used the force to find the theme. It was like a miniature Star Wars, with me as Luke Crossworder.

Any one else have Picard being BADdER than vis-√†-vis Kirk?

I did stop to ponder the philosophical meaning of FORMIdES I CAN SEE since formide is colorless. I‚Äôve heard that the 60s were a strange time, though.

Faster than yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, I solved this. Fun solving it, I had. I saw the SIXERS play the Lakers many moons ago at the Forum. Charles Barkley was still playing for the Sixers and was ejected from the game. Great game to catch in person. 
Dismissed from jury duty, I was!! üéâ
Someone else has probably pointed this out, but not knowing Prell dates you. As younger than a boomer.

Thiese song lyrics could have been written by Yoda:
‚ÄúWake, from your sleep
The drying of your tears
Today, we escape‚Äù

Instead, written by RADIOHEAD

[What solvers who don‚Äôt like the theme might say]
SATISFACTION, I CAN‚ÄôT GET NO

[What Sam might say as she guides solvers through the theme]
HOLD YOUR HAND, I WANT TO

[What fans of a twisted musical theme might say]
ROCK N ROLL, I LOVE

The last group, I am in. 

Thanks, Victor

Hopefully. We‚Äôll get some good ones that take people back to meaningful times

Always Love You, I Will
Through The Grapevine, I Heard It
Around, I Get
You Babe, I Got
Candy, I Want
For Loving You, I Hate Myself

Clearly Now, I Can See that I‚Äôm not the only one who was charmed by this puzzle. 

Fun Tonight, Everybody Have.
This was fun! Although had to look up a couple of the US based sports clues. You could say I was MISGUIDED by some tricky crosses today
I enjoyed this one. I understood the song titles right away but had to figure out what order to put them in. Funny!

Treasure Hunt--A typo in the Constructor Notes: 

" I guess the moral of this story is that you should do what you like doing. If you‚Äôre lucky, other people like it too. It not, at least you had a good time along the way."

See it, can you?

As far as other songs that fit the theme--they all have "I" in them so how about:

Loving You I Can't Stop.
Absolutely awful puzzle. Not impressed one bit.
Loved this puzzle, I did! Thanks for this, Victor!

As a former Ohioan, now living as a Michigander, but one who genuinely cares about college sports (or professional, for that matter) not one whit, I find the rivalry between OSU and the Catholepistemiad of Michigania (as it was originally named) a source of amusement. It's possible that the rivalry originated with the Toledo War of 1835, aka the Ohio‚ÄìMichigan War, should you care to type an en-dash. The C of M was founded in 1817 in Detroit by Fr. Gabriel Richard‚ÄîI bike by the site every morning on my way to work‚Äîand only relocated to ANN Arbor in 1841. At its inception, the school was endowed with thirteen didaxiim, or fields of study: in Anthropoglossica, Mathematica, Physiognostica, Physiosophica, Astronomia, Chymia, Iatrica, ≈íconomica, Ethica, Polemitactica, Di√´getica, Enn≈ìica, and Catholepistemia; and don't you dare split those digraphs! One might argue that the rival of Michigan is Michigan. That is to say, between the (renamed) University of Michigan vs. Michigan State University. As a result, one has to be careful about one's terminology: U of M vs. MSU, Wolverine vs. Spartan, Ann Arbor vs. East Lansing, or simply "Michigan" vs. "State." The rivalry is, in many ways, between Urban vs. Rural, Affluent vs. Salt-of-the-earth, Detroit metro vs. All the rest of Michigan; but, of course, this is a gross over-simplification. *** Here's some sunny music, in a minor alternating with A major: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JG33g_ELdeM&list=RDJG33g_ELdeM&start_radio=1

I love a puzzle with a theme this original and charming. Thank you Victor Barocas.

One nit: brand names are always a last resort. Brand names from the 1950s? Let's retire PRELL, once and for all.

Fitting that WILLIAM is wordplay-lover Mr. Shortz's first name in both English and Yodish.




Et tu, emu.
Loved it I did.
The force was strong with this one.
Clever puzzle this is!  My complements to Mister Barocas go!
Music titles might be challenging, but I sure know my shampoos. üòé Fun puzzle!

For those who like Spelling Bee, the New Yorker has a similar game called Shuffalo. The idea is to build increasingly longer words with the same letters, using each once. Every time you go to the next word, one more letter is added. I thought today's was a relatively easy one. https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/shuffalo/2025/12/03
Very charming puzzle, thanks!

Mildly amusing, it is...
...but in a Yoda-voice, you must say it.

"Solve. Or solve not. There is no try."

Clever crossword, but since I've never understood the enthusiasm for Star Wars (although I like Star Trek) and have not seen YODA films, the theme fell a little flat for me. I assume "wise counsellor" is ironic?

PRELL? I would never say a setter was lazy, that's daft, but I wish clues like this didn't get set.

Alternative clue for 30D:
[The Borg, among Star Trek nemeses]

I don't know Star Wars from Star Trek. I think I saw the former during its first run at a movie theater, but I was on a date and we had both partaken of a nickel bag. All I remember was a lot of pretty flashing lights. (Yes, I did inhale). I have seen the Yoda character many times, but had no idea of his idiosyncratic speaking style.

I had no trouble getting three of the four theme answers, since they were part of my musical coming of age. Didn't know Katy Perry's song ‚Äî too new for me. The theme reminded me, though, of my grandmother. As a student of languages, I can figure out the sentence structure of a person's native language by the way they speak English, and Grandma was no exception. She didn't speak English very well. They lived on the second floor of our two-family house, and there were several times when I was upstairs and grandpa had to go somewhere, but forgot something. She's say something like "Throw grandpa down the stairs his hat." So I smiled all through those theme answers.
Liked this, I did.

I really enjoyed this puzzle. I knew 29 and 44 across immediately and thought the theme had to do with gay anthems so I was puzzled by 68 across. And then I started on the downs and was thoroughly confused üòÄ and then the penny dropped. Great twist!

I‚Äôm going to try my best to say this in as grammatically correct a way as is humanly possible at this point:

‚ÄúThis is not the word order you were looking for.‚Äù


(Tried *and* done.)
When someone stole his mineral rights it took a lode off his mine.

I‚Äôm one of those who got a smile from this, though I figured my age had a lot to do with it, and others might be frustrated. I mean, I saw The Who perform I Can See for Miles in 1971. I watched Captain Kirk. Normally I‚Äôd be grumpy about a puzzle like this, so I understand if some didn‚Äôt like it. But I had fun with it. Some memories here. I even remember Prell.

Enjoyed this one. Typical slow start for me, but finally catching on to the theme was the big turning point and that's always a nice touch. 

Did my usual answer history searches today but didn't come up with anything all that interesting. Maybe I'll find another puzzle later. Or maybe not. 

...

A fun one this was. 

Looking forward to the new word order.

Hah!  I filled in CHIN for [Guarded area for many athletes], which gave me ACH! for [Forehead marker at the start of Lent], which brought a smile as I imagined seeing someone with that cry written in ashes on their forehead at the start of giving up dear things.

Charmed I was by [Words after ‚Äúhappily ever after‚Äù] for THE END, as it reminded me of how my heart warmed when I was a kid listening to fairy tales.  Charmed I was as well by Yoda‚Äôs endearing way of speaking.

Speaking of heart-warming, ANNE PATCHETT‚Äôs books.

I, who usually have trouble guessing a puzzle‚Äôs revealer ‚Äì had no trouble today.  It popped right in after I filled in the first theme answer.  And if you tell me it was obvious and easy LA LA LA LA LA LA LA.

I liked that Victor was just a Z short of a pangram and didn‚Äôt weaken the answer set trying to wrench that letter in.  I also liked the trio of three-letter palindromes (TAT, OSO, ASA).  

Much pleasure in the box, therefore, for me.  Victor, your puzzle did my heart good.  Thank you!

In the "Credit where credit is due" department: The photograph accompanying today's "Wordplay" column is not hard to "get": a word play on "unresolved", it shows a lo-res, inverted image of the Mona Lisa, that becomes hi-res(?) and right-side-up when viewed through a little crystal ball. The artist is Devorah Sperber, who, between 1999 and 2010, made a number of artworks copying iconic images, made from spools of thread. Unsurprisingly, her versions of the Mona Lisa were the most popular. https://www.devorahsperber.com/thread_works_index_html_and_2x2s/index.html Thanks, Sam, for sending me down this interesting rabbit hole.
I have not seen Prell in ages but can recall the scent from childhood.
I was frustrated!

Great fun!

Frustrating - but fair and satisfying - solve. The middle threw me - I originally had GEAR for anabolic steroids (too niche?) and PRELL crossing with HARE, DVORAK, and SIBERIA were just trivia items I didn‚Äôt know. Was able to get there with crosses, though. Good construction!

As hoped for, my usual late puzzle find. Did this one, but had forgotten it. Anyway - a Tuesday from May 19, 2020 by Trent H. Evans. Just some really fun clues. Here are the theme clues and answers: "This hot dog is absolute perfection!," said Tom ___ : WITHRELISH "You're making a grave mistake," said Tom ___: CRYPTICALLY "I can't find a flower for 'She loves me, she loves me not,'" said Tom ___ : LACKADAISICALLY "I've learned my lesson about feeding the tigers," said Tom ___ : OFFHANDEDLY "Many thanks for your help in Paris," said Tom ___ : MERCIFULLY Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/19/2020&g=38&d=A ....

Long stare at ASA, I needed, and chortling now, I am!

What fun - thank you! Off to do the Costco Erin in full Yoda voice now - this should be good.

PRELL was the go-to for soaping fountains in glory days gone by.
It wasn't me, honest.
Repeating what I've heard, I am only.
Found it a bit too easy for a Wednesday. Raced through the first half of the grid and found the trick pretty easily. Felt level of difficulty more suited to Monday
Enjoyable this was.
For 24 across, PEDs or Performance Enhancing Drugs, is the formal term for anabolic steroids. A more informal term for them would be gear or juice.

Since I don't know songs by their performers or bands or (often) their titles, this puzzle presented an extra challenge for me...Plus, YODA's speech pattern hadn't struck me as being all that consistent (or it's just been too long!)
When the SHERIFF appeared, it was a big help.  

Speaking of help, I had to call Security this morning when my walking buddy announced she was feeling shaky--and then fainted on the drive right in front of her house.  I got her down safely, but she is a little taller than I am despite being a featherweight, and she had a death grip on my arm, so she took me down with her.  Flat on my face, I was.  Ow, ow, ow.  We're both okay, but she was apparently dehydrated (according to the nurse who showed up with the security guard.)  At least we got our mile in first...

cute and clever!

but still short enough solve time that i am left wanting more

happy wednesday everyone!

In general loved this puzzle, I did . One minor nit to pick . I had Michigan State - ie MSU for the longest time . I am not a francophile - and did not know " a toi " . I hate getting tripped up by a foreign word I don't know in an English crossword . Just me ?? Plus .. Ohio State is certainly a rival , but Michigan State is the in state rival for certain - and both in the Big Ten .

Walked in I did to find my girl you kissed *smack smack*

I should've known what you'd do or do not

Oh no, not I, survive I will
As long as I know how to solve, I know this grid I'll fill
All day to finish I've got, and earn I will my gold star
Here in my galaxy that's away far far


This took me surprisingly long to compose, but it turned out really well(assuming you're not hung up on meter, consistency or continuity)!
I see what you did with that subhead.

Thanks for such a fun puzzle!
Just plain fabulous.
I can smell Prell right now.

Very fun puzzle!
Regarding Prell:  is the bottle green, or the shampoo itself?  
I remember my mom used to buy it because it was cheap and there were a lot of kids in my family.

Apparently, it is still made and is sold at stores like CVS and Walmart.

This puzzle, I loved.

It hit me at just the right moment and in just the right way.  I was so smart.  I knew the Gloria Gaynor song and inked it in.  Marley and Clapton?  Only one possible song, and it fit, and I was so proud of myself.  The Who?  First I thought of Pinball Wizard -- too short -- but then the right answer popped.

And then, none of the crosses fit.  Impossible words.  So, I thought I'd better take a closer look at the bottom right theme clue, which stumped me at first.  But my neighbor has a dog named Yoda (yes, he's that ugly), and next came a guffaw, followed by edits to my musical brilliance with the Yoda-esque word arrangement.

After that, the rest of the puzzle flew by.

Really, truly fun. Actually, sort of easy for a Wednesday once the theme was decoded.  But I give the author an OBIE, an ESPY and a standing ovation for bravery.

Thank you for 27A, and a reminder that my Buckeyes beat the pants off That Team Up North. No really, all the players receive a charm in the shape of a pair of gold pants to commemorate the victory. The high point of the afternoon was when Brutus crossed out the "M" in the snowy end zone.

Oh yeah, the rest of the puzzle. I enjoyed the Yoda theme, and it was nice to see RADIOHEAD.
A trivia fest that relies on you largely knowing titles of songs to get the answers? Pass. It‚Äôs a bit sad that a little trick is enough to get people to think this is a good puzzle.

Smile, I did.
Prell and its greenness was well known back in the day.
Not that it matters in any way, but surely Yoda would call the songs ‚ÄúSee for Miles I Can‚Äù, ‚ÄúShot the Sheriff I Did‚Äù and ‚ÄúKiss a Girl I Did‚Äù?
Loved this, thank you!!

I no longer see Prell on the shelves, but it was ubiquitous in TV adds and in stores in the day. Surely, you can remember Seinfeld?
Jerry uses "Prell, the hard stuff."

Yes..yes...Star Wars fan, I am! 
Like others I started with "We don't need no stinkin' revealer", and blithely filled in the older song titles. Bam - maybe I'm not the hotshot blockade running pilot I thought I was! 
PS I know a song from 2008 is now 17 years old (math - see how I did that? LOL), but It's out of my wheelhouse unless my kids or grandkids listened to it. Thank you, crosses!
Anything with Yoda I love :)
Really fun puzzle. Loved the theme.
Very clever, and great fun! Thanks.
All I had left was _VO_AK and was surprised when my desperate guess of the alternative keyboard layout cued the music.

Thank you to Sam & Mr. Barocas! This puzzle was immensely fun (and perfectly timed to improve what's otherwise been a bad day)!

I figured out the theme right away and totally loved it. PRELL brought back memories of shopping in the shampoo aisle with my mom.

I'm hitting the road today for a long drive across the state, and I'll definitely be playing that song by The Who once I'm on the highway! üõ£Ô∏è

One more puzzle find. Quite remarkable. A Sunday from December 5, 1976 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title: "Exam time." Some theme clues and answers: "What did Hartman snack on?" MARYHADALITTLELAMB "Where in church is Masterson?" BATSINTHEBELFRY "What is put on Basie's bed?" DOWNFORTHECOUNT "Where do Sandburg's pirates hide?" CARLSBADCAVERNS "What does the queen do at the corner?" VICTORIACROSSES "What is Elizabeth's tennis forte?" HERMAJESTYSSERVICE "How do you contact Tarkington?" PHONEBOOTH "Where does Sigmund park his ferries?" FREUDIANSLIPS Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/5/1976&g=97&d=A ....
I really liked the theme but the onslaught of trivia killed it. The center of the puzzle was unsolvable for this very reason.

Amusing to me that VILEST unlocked YODA  and the entire pizzle for me

Flee through it, because, the songs, know them I did.

What a fun, clever puzzle, Victor, and I really enjoyed your constructor notes! Thank you -- I look forward to your next one!

This puzzle made my day.

Really fun puzzle. The Yoda trick was a perfect Wednesday trick and made filling in the grid truly delightful. 

I have to disagree with Sam, though, and I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not the first. ‚ÄúThe problem with this [Wise counselor of sci-fi who might not be great at karaoke?]‚Äù is that he is a wise counselor of FANTASY. Thank you.

I thoroughly enjoyed this one, even though 29A got me on the first pass! I also learned all kinds of things from this one: I had heard of OBIEs but didn‚Äôt know they were for off-Broadway shows; didn‚Äôt know OLEO came from plants; didn‚Äôt know Bugs Bunny was a HARE; didn‚Äôt know linseed oil came FLAX. Now I am armed with more trivia to beat my nieces and nephews at video Trivial Pursuit (which we played this past weekend). üòä Hope y‚Äôall had a wonderful Thanksgiving!

Ah, good old Prell. Got a bottle of it in my teens at my hairdresser‚Äôs suggestion to strip the ‚Äútemporary‚Äù burgundy color with which I colored my light brown hair (in hindsight, maybe ‚Äústrip‚Äù isn‚Äôt a word I would want associated with the cleaning power of a product for my hair). Alas, though my hair was eventually less burgundy with the regular use of Prell, it did go through a period of being decidedly orange before returning to brown. 

And though I know this song isn‚Äôt by Gloria Gaynor, it‚Äôs the first one I thought of reading 29 across, so I will posit it as a song title option: ‚ÄúMy Bell, You Can Ring.‚Äù

This one was tough for me. I figured out the theme really quickly, but I am never good with song names or artist names so it really didn't help. Other than the Katy Perry song, I do know the others and could sing them, but I didn't know them by the clues. And the fill felt a bit tougher to me, especially in the middle. But I got 'er done [1975 song by Eric Carmen, per 68A]

I briefly thought I wasn't going to be able to complete it but I'm getting better at trusting myself to get there, so I took a break and came back to it. 

It didn't help that I left WILE as in e. coyote in 42A for so long. I know it doesn't make sense... it's an animal's name, not the type of animal, but I felt pretty sure until nothing there made sense and I took it out. 

Oh well! Tough one for me personally, but definitely enjoyable to puzzle out!  And in the end, SURVIVE, I did!
Only one letter needed correcting after my "once through and done"  finish: I had LAP instead of GAP.  Alas, I had been momentarily misluided!

So, off topic, but I have a question that I've been asking around about.  Minnesota has a very high population of Somali people, If you don't know, and we live right across the hall from a very lovely family from Somalia. We've known them a few years and though we're not like hanging out etc, we always talk to them when we cross paths, if they see us on our balcony etc... And they're comfortable to come over and borrow salt, things like that. Very neighborly both ways.

If any of you are following what's been going on recently with this community, then you know why I'm concerned about them and empathize with the fear they must be feeling. 

All this to say, I'd like to get them just some little thing, just a little friendly gesture that might help them feel supported at least by their neighbors. One friend mentioned dates as a possibility. In the past we've given their kids little treats like ice cream bars or popcorn and they really liked that, but that was usually more in the moment in a crossing of paths. Any suggestions of what might be a nice gift for this very sweet family?

A really FUN puzzle. PRELL. Now there's a blast from the past. What could possibly go wrong with having a glass bottle in a shower? The  one that really gave me fits was PEDS, but I was thinking on more common terms.
How delightful!! Thank you Victor.

Loved seeing PRELL make the scene! I'm old enough to remember their old television spots. 

One ad touted its "New!" unbreakable plastic bottle at a time when other shampoos and the like were still in silppery-when-wet-and-soapy and hazardously breakable glass. 

Another featured the ever-so-slow descent of a pearl (Prell - pearl) dropped into the top of a full (plastic) bottle. This proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that Prell's rich thickness would guarantee luxurious lather and amazing results! 

Gotta wonder if it's a first-time appearance in the NYT Crossword.
This felt very easy, even the gimmick.
PRELL is a little before my time so I thought of PERT for the green shampoo bottle! Alas, a letter short it is, as YODA would say.

Well, thank you Mr. Barocas for constructing a puzzle because you liked doing it, even though you knew it would not please everyone.

I could just hear Yoda say: ‚ÄúA girl, I kissed.‚Äù It made laugh out loud. Or should I say: out loud, I laughed.

@KRB
I don‚Äôt know how to sign myself, but according to some grammar guides I just checked, American Sign Language uses both subject-verb-object (‚ÄúThe boy kicked the ball.‚Äù) and object-subject-verb (‚ÄúThe ball, kicked the boy‚Äù) word orders, the latter of which is, of course, how Yoda speaks.

Incidentally, Japanese, Korean, and several other languages use subject-object-verb order. For example:
Japanese: Otokonoko wa / b≈çru o / ketta.
Literal translation: [A/the/an indefinite number of] boy(s) (grammatical topic-marking particle) / [the/a/an indefinite number of] ball(s) (accusative grammatical particle) / kicked.

Polish is extremely flexible when it comes to word order in a sentence. You can rearrange the words in almost any configuration and the result will still make sense. I guess it's because declension of nouns and conjugation of verbs make it clear what role every word plays in a sentence. 

Zrzuci≈Çem dziadkowi kapelusz ze schod√≥w - I threw the hat down the stairs to grandpa.

Zrzuci≈Çem dziadka w kapeluszu ze schod√≥w - I threw grandpa, who was wearing a hat, down the stairs.

Can you see the difference? Dziadkowi vs dziadka? That's declension, and it shows what's being done with or to grandpa in the sentence.

The first sentence will still mean the same in this (slightly awkward but not erroneous) version: Dziadkowi ze schod√≥w kapelusz zrzuci≈Çem. The word order is different but the meaning didn't change.

@Cherry Hey, thanks for sending me down the "rabbit hole"! :) Here's a probably not complete list of titles: A Wild Hare (1940): The first official Bugs Bunny cartoon, released on July 27, 1940. The Heckling Hare (1941): Features Bugs Bunny tormenting a dopey dog named Willoughby. Falling Hare (1943): Bugs battles a gremlin in a World War II-era setting. The Old Grey Hare (1944): Bugs battles Elmer Fudd, who is much older than usual. Herr Meets Hare (1945): An anti-Nazi propaganda short released during World War II. Hair-Raising Hare (1946): Features the first appearance of the monster Gossamer. Slick Hare (1947): A Friz Freleng-directed short. Long-Haired Hare (1949): A title that is a pun on "longhairs," a term for classical music lovers. Water, Water Every Hare (1952): A return to the monster-theme of Hair-Raising Hare. A fun example (Herr Meets Hare): https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=919309686139903
